awd_titl_txt: EAGER: ADAPT: AI-Enhanced Sampling for Lattice Field Theory and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will use Artificial Intelligence to greatly speed up theoretical calculations in elementary particle physics. Currently the detailed non-linear equations governing the interactions of elementary particles are not directly solvable, so a computational technique called Lattice Field Theory is used to approximately solve them at separate points in space (the lattice) and then combined to get an approximate result. The precision which can be obtained is only limited by computational time. Currently the largest High-Performance Computers in the world are kept busy with Lattice Field Theory equation solving. This work will apply a new technique called Normalizing Flows to greatly reduce the required compute time for these calculations. 

Normalizing flows are a class of deep generative models that can effectively model complex, high-dimensional distributions and have the potential to transform many areas of physics. These models are designed by composing many simple invertible neural network layers designed to efficiently compute the desired result. These flows can model the probability distribution of data from a real experiment and thus spend computational time only on the parts of the calculation that will dominate the required solution.  This award will develop these normalizing flows for lattice field theory. The work will also enhance public outreach in the New York Public School system and maintain an active Artificial Intelligence social media presence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award made possible two lines of complementary research: 1) the theory, development, and application of generative AI to problems underlying statistical physics and quantum field theory, and 2) the construction of novel numerical methods which has made possible an ab-initio study of the theory of strange metals.

 

1. The Standard Model of physics, a quantum field theory describing the interaction of the electromagnetic, strong, and weak forces, has proven to be remarkably descriptive of our world. The assembly of this theory has relied on new mathematical advances arising in harmony with precision experiments. Nonetheless, critical aspects of the theory remain inaccessible — in particular, the low-energy theory of the strong force is not amenable to the perturbative analysis which has revealed much about the electromagnetic and weak forces. In this domain, the theory must be discretized and solved numerically on a computer in a procedure known as Lattice QCD. This award facilitated the research of new solutions to this numerical simulation that are built on generative modeling — a technique arising in contemporary machine learning to model probability distributions. Through this award, new generative modeling methods were devised that capture the underlying geometry and symmetry inherent to the theory of the strong force, providing an inductive bias enabling orders of magnitude speedups compared to baseline methods. Like a neural network studying an image of a flower, which is designed to recognize the flower regardless of rotations and translations of it, these neural networks commute through the local "gauge symmetry" of the field theory.  These developments have made possible a scientific machine learning approach to studying the complete theory of QCD, and have situated the research team to be in a position to scale the methods to supercomputer levels in the coming year.

2. A number of materials experimentally studied over the last half century exhibit exotic behavior, such as becoming superconducting at high temperature. A coherent theory of the phase diagram describing these phenomena is still lacking, including a reason for the linear-in-temperature resistivity of some of these materials which are known as strange metals. While recent theoretical approaches have provided some insight into these phenomena, these are notoriously difficult to study analytically due to their strong correlations. As such, there is a critical need for numerical methods which can handle this type of problem. A primary obstacle in the computational formulation of fermionic systems is the evaluation of the determinant of a very large matrix which captures the interaction of the bosonic and fermionic degrees of freedom. Through a technological exchange between lattice QCD and condensed matter, we created new numerical methods for the simulation of these disordered, strongly interacting electronic systems.  This resulting method provides a multiscale algorithm for the simulation of systems with a fermi surface and has provided new insights into the phase diagram of disordered metals.
